title: Bookbinding: Retchoso binding (maybe)
content:
Well, this is an account of the way I understood the retchoso binding method, as described [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611/http:/homepages.nildram.co.uk/~dawe5/bookbinding_pages/BB_welcome2.html)  
Maybe someone more expert than me can correct me if I’m wrong, otherwise you can find an explanation of rather simple way to bind a multisection book that open very flat that can be useful to bind your own notebook.

I started preparing the signatures and making the holes for sewing. Then I started sewing from the central signature in that way (red dashed lines are when the thread is _inside_ the signatures)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/retch_1_4007.gif)

Then when I reached one side I made returned toward the central signature and continue sewing until I reached the back of the book

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/retch_2_5498.gif)

And I returned back to the central signature where i stopped making a knot

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/retch_3_6479.gif)

When I finished with the upper part of the book, I made the same thing, with another thread, for the lower part. When I reached the end in the center of the book, I close the thread, like the other, with a knot and then with another pair of knots I joined the upper and lower threads (I don’t know if you _really_ need to do that.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/retch_4_6118.gif)

I show you the resulting book (not so nice, I’m not very careful when I do that kind of things):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/typ_spine_5225.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/typ_center_6394.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081201080611im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/typ_open_5092.jpg)
